p.s: This statement in Brian Pollard's extract victimizes the employers and demonizes the workers.
I would say this couldn't be farther from the truth - especially in developing countries.
Conditions and power dynamics in developing countries such as Bangladesh resemble those of the industrial revolution - unions are needed there.
But that is not what the comment is refferingreferring to.
It is refferingreferring western countries - those who have already went through the abysmal conditions of the industrial revolution.
And I still think this couldn't be farther from the truth.
Take for example Amazon, McDonald's, any clothing making company - not only do they have workers abroad - in which case unions would help them, but they are also exploitive here!
Paying minimum wage while demanding long hours, overtime and firing if not complied with is very similar to the practises of the past.
Unions are still needed globally and here too.
Though I agree that ideally legislation and our moral code would suffice - sadly they do not.
